desc: ARID1B, a tumor suppressor involved in transcriptional regulation, is mutated in a diverse range of cancers.

The ARID1B gene encodes the ARID1B protein, a DNA-binding subunit of the BAF complex which is involved in ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling (PMID: 15170388).This complex plays a role in altering chromatin structure, a process that is necessary for various cellular functions, including transcription, DNA synthesis and DNA repair (PMID: 10757798, 21900401, reviewed in PMID: 25387058). ARID1B can substitute for ARID1A in BAF complexes making these two proteins mutually exclusive components of the complex despite ARID1A being more commonly present (PMID: 15170388). Like ARID1A, germline mutations in ARID1B result in Coffin-Siris syndrome (PMID: 22426308, 22426309). Some patients with germline ARID1B mutations or deletions may present with early-onset malignancy such as papillary thyroid cancer that was found in a 27 year-old man with a germline 6q25 deletion that included the ARID1B locus (PMID: 24700687). Inactivating ARID1B mutations have been identified in breast cancer (PMID: 22722201), hepatocellular carcinoma (PMID: 22634756), gynecologic carcinosarcoma (PMID: 25233892), pancreatic cancer (PMID: 22233809) and medulloblastoma (PMID: 22820256). In neuroblastoma, the most frequent alteration seen was intragenic deletion resulting in either a frameshift mutation or removal of the start site, both of which are predicted to result in loss of function (PMID: 23202128). ARID1B was identified as a specific vulnerability in ARID1A-mutant cancer cell lines using a short hairpin RNA (shRNA) screen, suggesting that ARID1B may be a therapeutic target for cancers with inactivating ARID1A mutations (PMID: 24562383).
